last_episode_to_air.name: A Scenario of Japan's Collapse
last_episode_to_air.overview: The Prime Minister is informed that in a worst case scenario, a third of the country — including the Tokyo area — will become uninhabitable for decades.

name: THE DAYS
overview: Blamed by some, hailed as heroes by others, those involved with Fukushima Daiichi face a deadly, invisible threat — an unprecedented nuclear disaster.

episodes.name: The Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant Is Submerged
episodes.overview: March 11, 2011; 225 kilometers from Tokyo, a 15 meter high tsunami hits the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station, damaging one of the cooling systems.

episodes.name: No Need to Evacuate
episodes.overview: While still unable to get an assessment of the situation from Fukushima Daiichi, the government tells the public to stay calm and remain in their homes.

episodes.name: Radioactive Emissions Will Be Minimal
episodes.overview: Pressure in the containment vessel starts to rapidly rise. With a catastrophic explosion imminent, TOEPCO suggests releasing the gas into the atmosphere.

episodes.name: It Would Mean Turning Our Backs on Fukushima
episodes.overview: With the power still down, the valves will have to be opened manually. With heavy hearts, some workers ask if they can evacuate to a safer location.

episodes.name: Our Company Has Lost Its Mind
episodes.overview: Station Manager Yoshida decides to use seawater as a cooling source, but TOEPCO headquarters tells him to wait for authorization from the administration.

episodes.name: I Can No Longer Leave Here Alive
episodes.overview: When pressure in the containment vessel finally starts to decrease, TOEPCO headquarters want on-site workers to get back to work, but Yoshida is wary.

episodes.name: Decide the Conditions for Evacuation
episodes.overview: As the administration and TOEPCO headquarters grow increasingly impatient, Station Manager Yoshida asks for permission to evacuate some on-site workers.

episodes.name: A Scenario of Japan's Collapse
episodes.overview: The Prime Minister is informed that in a worst case scenario, a third of the country — including the Tokyo area — will become uninhabitable for decades.
